title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this session, you should be able to:

Define what a control system is in engineering terms.
Distinguish among process control, servomechanisms, and discrete-state control systems.
Identify and describe the main elements in a process-control loop: process, sensor, error detector, controller, final control element, actuator.
Interpret and sketch a basic process-control block diagram.
Explain key performance criteria: stability, steady-state regulation, and transient response.
Use basic quantitative criteria (e.g., error, settling time, minimum area, quarter-amplitude) to evaluate control performance.


Read objectives slowly; connect them explicitly to later topics in the course (PID control, sensor selection, PLCs, etc.).
Stress that you’ll revisit this same block diagram in many later lectures: once they really internalize it, a lot of control theory feels less abstract.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Human Progress and Control
Human technological progress has been driven by better ways to control the environment.

Keeping room temperature at \(21^\circ\mathrm{C}\)
Guiding spacecraft to Jupiter
Manufacturing integrated circuits with nanometer precision

All these are examples of control systems:

Methods to force parameters in the environment to have specific values.







Note


Key Idea A control system is the collection of elements needed to ensure some variable behaves the way we want it to, despite disturbances.




Relate to common ECE experiences:

Voltage regulators forcing output to 5 V.
Clock generation circuits keeping frequency constant.
Wi-Fi power control keeping signal within limits.

Make the connection that “process control” is the industrial version of these same ideas.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Natural vs Artificial Control
Control is not just a human invention.

Biological systems use natural process control:

Body temperature regulation
Heart rate and blood pressure
Glucose level control


Engineering systems use artificial control:

Initially: human operators read gauges and turn valves.
Now: automatic control using instruments, electronics, computers.


Briefly ask students: “What’s an example of ‘natural control’ you know from biology?” to make the concept stick.
Then transition: we will now study the artificial analog of such regulation, focusing on industrial processes.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Process Control: Basic Objective
In process control, the objective is to regulate the value of some quantity.

To regulate: keep a variable at a desired value despite disturbances.
Desired value: reference value or setpoint, usually denoted \(r\).

Examples:

Maintain tank level at \(H\).
Maintain reactor temperature at \(150^\circ\mathrm{C}\).
Maintain motor speed at 1500 rpm.







Important


Regulation ≈ “hold at a setpoint.”




Clarify vocabulary:

“Regulation” vs “tracking” (which comes later with servomechanisms).
Use notation: actual controlled variable \(c(t)\), setpoint \(r\).

Tell them: “By the end of the course, when you hear ‘regulate temperature at 150°C,’ you should immediately picture a loop with process, sensor, controller, actuator.”

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Tank-Level Example: The Process


We start with a simple process: a tank with inflow and outflow.

Inflow: \(Q_{\mathrm{in}}\)
Outflow: \(Q_{\mathrm{out}}\)
Liquid level (height): \(h\)

Given relation:
\[
Q_{\mathrm{out}} = K\sqrt{h}
\]

Higher level \(h\) → higher outflow \(Q_{\mathrm{out}}\).
If \(Q_{\mathrm{out}} > Q_{\mathrm{in}}\): level drops.
If \(Q_{\mathrm{out}} < Q_{\mathrm{in}}\): level rises.





Tank process: inflow, outflow, level h, desired level H


Figure 1: Objective is to regulate the level \(h\) to desired value \(H\).


Emphasize: for now, no controller, no human—just physics.
Mention units: - \(h\) in ft (height). - \(Q\) in gal/min. - \(K\) given in gal/min per \(\mathrm{ft}^{1/2}\).
They will later see how such nonlinear process relations affect controller design.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Self-Regulation of the Tank
This process is self-regulating.

For some constant \(Q_{\mathrm{in}}\), the level \(h\) changes until \(Q_{\mathrm{out}} = Q_{\mathrm{in}}\).
At that point, \(h\) stops changing (steady state).

However:

The steady-state level is not necessarily the level we want.
If \(Q_{\mathrm{in}}\) changes, the level changes to a new value.







Warning


Self-regulation ≠ Control to a specified setpoint. It just finds some equilibrium, not necessarily your desired \(H\).




Draw on the board:

Start with some initial \(h\).
Show how a mismatch in flows causes level to change over time.

Explain that many physical systems “settle” somewhere, but that doesn’t mean they are controlled in the sense needed for engineering specifications.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Example 1: Self-Regulation Calculation
Problem
The tank has the relation
\[
Q_{\mathrm{out}} = K\sqrt{h}
\]
with

\(h\) in ft,
\(K = 1.156\;(\mathrm{gal/min})/\mathrm{ft}^{1/2}\),
Inflow \(Q_{\mathrm{in}} = 2\;\mathrm{gal/min}\).

At what value of \(h\) will the level stabilize due to self-regulation?

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Example 1: Solution
At steady state (self-regulation):
\[
Q_{\mathrm{out}} = Q_{\mathrm{in}}
\] So
\[
2 = 1.156\sqrt{h}
\] Solve for \(h\):
\[
h = \left(\frac{Q_{\mathrm{out}}}{K}\right)^2
  = \left(\frac{2\;\mathrm{gal/min}}{1.156\;(\mathrm{gal/min})/\mathrm{ft}^{1/2}}\right)^2
  \approx 3\;\mathrm{ft}
\]
So the tank level will stabilize at 3 ft.






Note


This is a process property, not a controlled setpoint. If you changed \(Q_{\mathrm{in}}\), the self-regulated level would change.




Ask: “If I double \(Q_{\mathrm{in}}\), will \(h\) double?”
No—because \(Q_{\mathrm{out}} = K\sqrt{h}\), so \(h \propto Q_{\mathrm{in}}^2\).
Use this to highlight that the process may be nonlinear—a key issue for control design.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
From Self-Regulation to Human Control
Suppose we want to maintain the level at a specific value \(H\), regardless of \(Q_{\mathrm{in}}\).
We add:

A sensor to measure level, via a sight tube \(S\).
A valve on the outlet to adjust \(Q_{\mathrm{out}}\).



The human strategy:

Read the actual level \(h\) on sight tube \(S\).
Compare \(h\) to the target level \(H\).
If \(h > H\): open valve → \(Q_{\mathrm{out}}\) increases → level falls.
If \(h < H\): close valve → \(Q_{\mathrm{out}}\) decreases → level rises.
Repeat small adjustments to keep level near \(H\).





Human regulating tank level via sight tube and valve


Figure 2: Human-aided level control using a sight tube and valve.


Point out roles:

Controlled variable: tank level \(h\).
Manipulated (controlling) variable: valve opening → affects \(Q_{\mathrm{out}}\).
Sensor: sight tube.
Controller: human brain.
Control element: valve.

Ask them to imagine a water tank in a lab and how they would manually keep level constant.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
From Human to Automatic Control
To automate, we replace the human with instruments.


Automatic system elements:

Sensor: measures level and outputs signal \(s\) (voltage, current, pressure).
Controller: electronic or computer-based device that:

Receives measurement \(s\),
Knows the setpoint \(H\),
Computes control signal \(u\).

Actuator + Valve: receive \(u\) and adjust outflow.





Automatic level control with sensor, controller, actuator, valve


Figure 3: Automatic level-control system replacing the human.

When such automatic control is applied to processes, we call it process control.

Stress that the logic of the task hasn’t changed—only who/what does it.
Point to the idea of feedback: the sensor measures output, which is compared to setpoint, and the result is fed back to change the input.
Connect this to ECE language:

Sensor output \(s\) might be a 4–20 mA signal.
Controller might be a microcontroller running PID logic.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Servomechanisms vs Process Control


Another key class of control systems: servomechanisms.

Objective: make a variable follow a time-varying reference.
This is tracking control, not just regulation to a constant setpoint.

Example: Robot arm motion from point \(A\) to point \(B\).
Servomechanism traits:

Controlled variable: position, angle, velocity, etc.
Reference \(r(t)\) is a trajectory over time.
Controller forces actual motion to follow \(r(t)\).





Robot arm moving from A to B using servomechanisms


Figure 4: Servomechanism-based robot arm control.







Note


Process control: keep variable near constant setpoint.
Servomechanism: make variable track a varying reference.




Help them map this to ECE:

DC/BLDC motor position control in robotics → servomechanism.
Power supply voltage regulation → process control.

Mention that although this book focuses on process control, many concepts overlap with servo control (feedback, stability, etc.).

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Discrete-State Control Systems
Discrete-state control: controls sequences of events (on/off, start/stop).
Example: Paint manufacturing sequence:

Fill tank to a certain level.
Heat mixture to set temperature (with a temperature control loop).
Maintain temperature for a set time.
Start pump to transfer to next tank.
Start mixer; mix for specified duration.

Each step is: On or off, true or false, started or stopped.
These systems are:

Often implemented using PLCs (Programmable Logic Controllers).
Described using ladder logic, state machines, etc.


Stress that in a real plant, both types of control coexist:

Continuous loops (flow, temperature, pressure).
Discrete sequencing (start heater, open valve, alert alarm).

Tie to digital design: discrete-state control is similar to synchronous state machines, only with real-world actuators.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Generic Process-Control System Elements
To study control systems in a general way, we identify functional elements:

Process / Plant
Measurement (Sensor + Conditioning)
Error Detector
Controller
Control Element (Final Control Element)
Actuator

We’ll see how these appear in a block diagram, independent of the physical details.

Prepare to show Figure 5 and explicitly map each block to the tank-level example.
Use consistent notation:

(\(c\)) controlled variable,
(\(u\)) manipulated variable (control input to process),
(\(r\)) setpoint,
(\(b\)) measured value,
(\(e\)) error.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Element 1: Process (Plant)

The process (or plant) is what we’re trying to control.
In the tank example:

Tank, fluid, inlet/outlet pipes, and their dynamics.


General characteristics:

May involve many variables (temperature, pressure, flow, composition).
May be:

Single-variable process (control one main variable), or
Multivariable process (several interrelated variables).








Note


In ECE, “plant” could be a motor, a DC-DC converter, an antenna system, etc.




Underline: in control theory, we often model the plant by differential equations or transfer functions.
Students will later learn how to derive simple models and how their structure affects stability and performance.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Element 2: Measurement & Sensor
To control a variable, we must measure it.
Measurement:

Conversion of physical variable → analog signal:

Pneumatic pressure,
Electrical voltage/current,
Digital code.


Sensor: device that performs the initial measurement and energy conversion.

Example: level sensor converting height to 4–20 mA.







Note


All sensors are transducers, but not all transducers are sensors.

Sensor: physical variable → signal.
Transducer (general): any signal form → another signal form.





Give some instrumentation examples:

Thermocouple: temperature → voltage.
Strain gauge: strain → resistance → voltage.
Pressure transmitter: pressure → 4–20 mA.

Explain “signal conditioning” (amplification, filtering, linearization) that usually follows the raw sensor.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Element 3: Error Detector
We compare the setpoint \(r\) to the measured value \(b\).

Error signal:

\[
e = r - b
\]

\(e\) has magnitude and sign (polarity).

Although often embedded inside the controller, we conceptually separate it as:

A summing junction or subtractor.







Important


Error is the core quantity the controller reacts to.




Relate to the human example:

Human mentally computes “am I above or below the desired level?”

Later, when doing block diagrams, show the \(\oplus\) symbol with incoming arrows \(r\) and \(-b\), output \(e\).

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Element 4: Controller
The controller receives the error \(e\) and decides how to act.
Roles:

Evaluate error over time.
Output control signal \(p\) (or \(u\), depending on notation) to drive the process.

Implementation forms:

Human operator (early systems).
Pneumatic or analog electronic circuits.
Digital controllers: microprocessors, PLCs, embedded systems.

Typical controller logic: Proportional (P), Integral (I), Derivative (D) actions → PID control.






Tip


The controller “translates” error into an appropriate manipulation of the process.




Stress that in modern process control, controllers are increasingly software running on industrial computers or PLCs.
Mention that tuning the controller (choosing gains, time constants) is a key engineering decision.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Element 5: Control Element & Actuator
Final Control Element (Control Element):

The device that directly influences the process variable.
Examples:

Control valve.
Variable-speed drive for a motor.


Actuator:

Intermediate device converting controller’s low-energy signal → physical action.
Examples:

Motorized valve operator.
Power electronics controlling a motor.








Note


Actuator: small signal in → big energy out.




Map to ECE:

DAC or PWM output from microcontroller → gate driver → MOSFET bridge → motor.
Controller output (= small electronic signal) can’t by itself turn a large valve or motor.

Clarify that in some small systems, actuator and final control element might be integrated as one device.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Generic Process-Control Block Diagram





Figure 5: Generic block diagram of a feedback control loop



Signals:

\(r\): reference (setpoint).
\(c\): controlled variable (process output).
\(b\): measured value (feedback signal).
\(e = r - b\): error.
\(p\): controller output to control element.
\(u\): manipulated variable into process.




Walk through the loop slowly:

Setpoint \(r\) enters the summing junction.
Measured value \(b\) is subtracted → error \(e\).
Controller converts \(e\) into output \(p\).
Control element (valve, etc.) converts \(p\) into manipulated variable \(u\).
Process converts \(u\) into controlled output \(c\).
Measurement block converts \(c\) into \(b\) for feedback.

Stress: This loop is the canonical picture of feedback control.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
The Feedback Loop Concept
Notice the closed path of signals in Figure 5:

Process output \(c\) is measured as \(b\).
Error \(e = r - b\) is computed.
Controller adjusts input \(u\) to process.
Process output changes, and the cycle repeats.

This is a feedback loop.

The system uses information about its output to continuously correct itself.







Important


A process-control loop is typically a feedback loop. Feedback can both improve performance and cause instability if misused.




Explain that feedback is a powerful concept appearing in many domains:

Electronic amplifiers (negative feedback).
Control of drones and robots.
Biological systems (hormone regulation).

Mention that later in the course, they’ll study stability criteria and frequency-domain analysis for such loops.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Evaluating Control System Performance
We now ask: How well is the control system working?
We use error as the performance measure:
\[
e(t) = r - c(t)
\]
Three main objectives:

Stability
Good steady-state regulation
Good transient regulation

Tuning the control loop = adjusting it to balance these objectives.

Emphasize: there is no free lunch—better steady-state performance often comes at the cost of worse transient behavior or reduced stability margin.
They will later see how tuning PID gains shapes this tradeoff.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Objective 1: Stability

Purpose of control: regulate a variable by acting on the process.
If the controller acts too aggressively or incorrectly, it can cause instability.




Figure 7: Initially, uncontrolled drift. After control is turned on, variable moves to setpoint, then later develops growing oscillations due to instability.








Warning


A control system can cause a system to become unstable. Tight control (fast response) often risks instability.




Ask: “Does adding control always make a system better?” Then show the figure—answer: not necessarily.
Relate to audio feedback (microphone + speaker “howl”): that’s an unstable loop.
Later, they’ll learn about gain margins and phase margins as formal stability measures.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Objective 2: Steady-State Regulation
Steady-state regulation:

How small is the error after transient effects die out?

Often specified as an acceptable band:

Allowable deviation \(\pm \Delta c\) around setpoint.
Example:

Setpoint \(150^\circ\mathrm{C}\).
Allowable band: \(148^\circ\mathrm{C} \le c \le 152^\circ\mathrm{C}\).


Goal: Minimize steady-state error while maintaining stability.






Note


Steady-state performance is about accuracy of long-term regulation.




Introduce the idea of offset: when the controlled variable settles at a value slightly different from setpoint.
Mention that integral action (I) in PID is often added to eliminate steady-state error, but again, this can worsen transient behavior.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Objective 3: Transient Regulation
Transient regulation asks: How does the system behave when a sudden change occurs?
Two main types of transients:

Setpoint change:

Example: change temperature setpoint from \(150^\circ\mathrm{C}\) to \(160^\circ\mathrm{C}\).

Disturbance/change in other variables:

Example: sudden change in inlet flow or feed composition.


Key questions:

How large is the temporary deviation from desired value?
How long does it take to return close to the setpoint?

This is often called the transient response.






Important


Good transient regulation = small overshoot and short time to settle.




Show simple sketches of good vs poor transient responses (even hand-drawn on whiteboard).
Make sure students understand:

You can’t judge a controller just by its final value.
The path it takes to get there (overshoot, oscillation) also matters.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Overall Evaluation Criteria
We evaluate a control system by:

Ensuring stability (no unbounded oscillations).
Assessing steady-state error (accuracy of long-term regulation).
Assessing transient response:

To setpoint changes.
To disturbances.


The process of adjusting the control loop to meet these criteria is called tuning.

State that later in the course they’ll learn practical tuning rules (e.g., Ziegler–Nichols, Cohen–Coon) and see how such rules implicitly target certain performance criteria (e.g., quarter-amplitude damping).

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Damped (Overdamped) Response


In one tuning approach, we desire a damped response:

Error does not oscillate around the setpoint.
It moves in one direction toward the new value and stays there.

Measures:

Duration \(t_D\):

For setpoint change: time from 10% to 90% of final change.
For transient: time from disturbance start until variable is within 4% of reference again.

Maximum error \(e_{\max}\) during the transient.

Tradeoffs:

You can get smaller \(e_{\max}\) at cost of larger \(t_D\), and vice versa.





Figure 8: Damped response to setpoint and transient changes




Explain:

Faster response (small \(t_D\)) may cause larger peak error.
Slower, more cautious response gives smaller overshoot but takes longer.

Relate to everyday experience—turning a steering wheel sharply vs smoothly.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Cyclic (Underdamped) Response
Another tuning approach allows oscillatory (cyclic) transient response.



Figure 9: Setpoint and disturbance responses with oscillations (cyclic response)


Measures:

Maximum error \(e_{\max}\).
Settling time \(t_D\): time from when error first exceeds allowable band until it returns within band and stays there.

Again, tuning changes:

Number of oscillations.
Amplitude of oscillations.
Settling time.







Warning


Cyclic response is acceptable only if oscillations are damped and stay within acceptable error limits.




Relate to second-order system responses in classical control: “underdamped” vs “overdamped.”
Mention that some oscillation can be acceptable if it results in faster settling than an overdamped response.

title: Introduction to Process Control
section: Quantitative Cyclic Criteria: Minimum Area & Quarter-Amplitude
text:
Quantitative Cyclic Criteria: Minimum Area & Quarter-Amplitude
Two standard cyclic tuning criteria:


Minimum Area Criterion

Define error-area:

\[
A = \int |e(t)|\,dt
\]

Tune controller to minimize \(A\) for a given excitation.
Interpreted as minimizing the total cumulative error over time.

Shaded region = area under \(|e(t)|\).

Quarter-Amplitude Criterion

In oscillatory response, each peak amplitude is ¼ of the previous:

\[
a_2 = \frac{a_1}{4},\quad
a_3 = \frac{a_2}{4},\ \dots
\]

Produces a quickly decaying oscillation.
Historically popular in process control tuning (e.g., Ziegler–Nichols).





Minimum area and quarter-amplitude criteria


Figure 10: Minimum area and quarter-amplitude response shapes.

Explain what \(|e(t)|\) means—absolute value ensures positive contribution from both sides of the setpoint.
Point out that these criteria are sometimes more theoretical; in practice, engineers use trial, simulation, and experience but still think in terms of these tradeoffs.

Explain that this is not yet a full feedback loop model, but a simple first-order response is often a decent approximation of many process-control loops near operating points.
Ask students to:

Increase τ → see slower response.
Increase K → see larger steady-state output.

Use this to prepare them for the idea of time constant and gain in dynamic models and how they impact tuning.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Summary / Key Points

Control systems force environmental or process variables to have desired values.
Process control focuses on regulating variables (like level, temperature, flow) to constant setpoints despite disturbances.
Servomechanisms perform tracking of time-varying references (e.g., robot arm motion).
Discrete-state control systems manage sequences of events (on/off, start/stop) and are often implemented using PLCs.
A generic process-control loop includes:

Process (plant).
Measurement & sensor.
Error detector \(e = r - b\).
Controller.
Control element (final control element) and actuator.

Formula & Notation Summary
Key variables and formulas used in this session:

Flow–level relation in tank:

\[
Q_{\mathrm{out}} = K\sqrt{h}
\]

Self-regulated level for given \(Q_{\mathrm{in}}\):

\[
Q_{\mathrm{out}} = Q_{\mathrm{in}} \Rightarrow
h = \left(\frac{Q_{\mathrm{out}}}{K}\right)^2
\]

Error definition:

\[
e(t) = r - c(t)
\]

The block diagram view groups these into functional blocks to simplify analysis.
Tie to ECE instrumentation: 4–20 mA is robust for industrial noise, long cable runs; 3–15 psi was used widely in older pneumatic systems.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this session, you should be able to:

Define control error and describe the practical objectives of a process-control system.
Distinguish stability, steady-state regulation, and transient regulation, and interpret typical response plots.
Explain and compare analog, digital, and ON/OFF control in real-world systems.
Describe ADC/DAC roles and the structure of supervisory and direct digital control.
Interpret basic process-control drawings (P&IDs) and standard signal conventions (4–20 mA, 3–15 psi).
Use SI and English units, metric prefixes, and define accuracy, sensitivity, hysteresis, resolution, and linearity.


You don’t need to memorize every definition immediately, but you should come away being able to:

Look at a control loop and talk about its performance in a structured way.
Read an industrial diagram and understand what the signals and boxes mean.
Do quick back-of-the-envelope checks involving units, percent error, and resolution.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Roadmap

Control System Evaluation

Error and control objectives
Stability, steady-state, transient response
Damped and cyclic criteria (minimum area, quarter amplitude)

Analog & Digital Processing

Analog vs digital data
ON/OFF, analog, and digital control (supervisory, DDC, smart sensors, fieldbus)

Units & Standards in Process Control

SI base units, metric prefixes, conversions
4–20 mA and pneumatic standards
Accuracy, resolution, linearity, P&IDs



Use the roadmap slide to frame the lecture as three big ideas. Students often already know a bit about PID and ADCs from prior courses; tie that prior knowledge explicitly to the new process-control context.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Control Error and Objective
The basic performance variable in feedback control is the error:
\[
e(t) = r - c(t)
\]

\(r\): setpoint or reference (often constant, sometimes time-varying).
\(c(t)\): controlled (measured) variable.
\(e(t)\): difference between desired and actual value.

Ideal but impossible goal: make \(e(t) = 0\) for all \(t\).
Realistic goal: keep the error small enough and well-behaved in time for the process requirements.






Important


Three practical control objectives

The system must be stable.
It should have good steady-state regulation (small long-term error).
It should have good transient regulation (acceptable behavior during changes and disturbances).





Emphasize: controllers only act when there is an error. If the error were identically zero, the controller output would be constant and the loop would be pointless.
In real plants, “good enough” error is set by economic, safety, and quality constraints, not by math perfection.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
section: Stability – Why Controllers Can Make Things Worse
text:
Stability – Why Controllers Can Make Things Worse


A controller changes the process input based on measurement feedback. If tuned improperly, this feedback can destabilize the process.

Before control: output drifts randomly.
After control is turned on: initially regulated near setpoint.
Later: oscillations grow → instability caused by the control loop.





FIGURE 7: A control system can actually cause a system to become unstable.










Warning


Tightening control (increasing gain, making it more aggressive) usually improves performance up to a point, then dramatically increases instability risk.




Draw an analogy with driving a car: over-correcting steering at high speed leads to increasing swerves and possibly a crash.
Stability is the first objective: if it’s unstable, nothing else matters.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Interactive: Visualizing an Unstable Response







Ask students to edit the gain k and re-run:

Small k → slow but stable.
Larger k → faster response, then overshoot and possible divergence.

This simple discrete-time model mimics how aggressive control can trigger oscillations or blow-up.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Steady-State Regulation
Steady-state regulation focuses on the long-term error after all transients die out.

Goal: minimize steady-state error.
Often specified as an allowable band around setpoint: \(\pm \Delta c\).

Example:

Target temperature: \(150^{\circ}\text{C}\).
Allowable variation: \(\pm 2^{\circ}\text{C}\).
Acceptable range: \(148^{\circ}\text{C} \le c(t) \le 152^{\circ}\text{C}\).

If the output drifts beyond this band, the control system must act to bring it back.






Tip


Steady-state performance is usually improved by integral action in a PID controller, but at the cost of slower transients or increased oscillation risk.




Point out that process engineers choose \(\Delta c\) based on product tolerance, energy cost, and safety. Steady-state performance is not just a math nicety; it dictates waste, off-spec product, and energy efficiency.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Transient Regulation
Transient regulation describes how the controlled variable behaves during sudden changes:

Setpoint changes (e.g., jump from \(150^{\circ}\text{C}\) to \(160^{\circ}\text{C}\)).
Disturbances (e.g., inlet flow or ambient temperature suddenly changes).

Key questions:

How fast does the system reach the new setpoint?
How big is the maximum error (overshoot or undershoot)?
Does it ring/oscillate, and how long until it “settles”?







Note


Transient response is usually characterized by:

Duration \(t_D\) (rise/settling time).
Maximum error \(e_{\max}\).
Whether the response is damped or cyclic/oscillatory.





Connect to earlier control courses: these correspond to time-domain specs like rise time, peak time, percent overshoot, and settling time for second-order systems.
Here, though, the textbook uses a slightly different but conceptually equivalent notation \(t_D, e_{\max}\).

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Evaluation Criteria – Big Picture
How do we judge how “good” a control loop is?

Stability:

Output remains bounded for bounded inputs.
No growing oscillations or runaway behavior.

Steady-State Response:

How small is the long-term error?
How well does it stay within the allowable band?

Transient Response:

How does it respond to setpoint steps and disturbances?
Tradeoff between speed (short \(t_D\)) and overshoot (small \(e_{\max}\)).

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Damped Response Criteria
In damped response, the error does not change sign; it approaches the setpoint monotonically.
Key metrics:

Duration \(t_D\):

For a setpoint change: time for output to go from 10% to 90% of the total change.
For a disturbance: time from the start of disturbance until output is within 4% of reference.

Maximum error \(e_{\max}\):

Peak deviation from the reference during the transient.


Different tuning → different \((e_{\max}, t_D)\) pairs for the same input.






Tip


Process designers must choose a compromise: - Smaller \(e_{\max}\) but longer \(t_D\), or - Larger \(e_{\max}\) but shorter \(t_D\).




Ask students: “If you’re designing temperature control for a sensitive semiconductor furnace, which do you prioritize: smaller overshoot or faster settling?”
Get them to articulate tradeoffs explicitly; this will foreshadow design exercises later in the course.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Cyclic (Underdamped) Response


Sometimes the desired response is allowed to oscillate around the setpoint.
In cyclic response:

Output oscillates about reference.
Parameters of interest:

Maximum error \(e_{\max}\).
Duration / settling time \(t_D\):

From when error first exceeds allowable band
To when it returns within the band and stays there.



Again, tuning adjusts the balance between overshoot and speed.

 



Relate this to standard second-order underdamped responses (ζ < 1).
In many industrial loops, mild oscillations are acceptable or even preferred, as long as they are decaying and within tolerance.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
section: Cyclic Tuning Criteria: Minimum Area and Quarter Amplitude
text:
Cyclic Tuning Criteria: Minimum Area and Quarter Amplitude


Two common criteria for oscillatory responses:

Minimum-area criterion

Minimize area under \(|e(t)|\) vs. time curve: \[
A = \int |e(t)|\,dt = \text{minimum}
\]
Intuitively: minimize “total error energy” during the transient.

Quarter-amplitude criterion

Each peak is 1/4 of the previous: \[
a_2 = \frac{a_1}{4},\quad a_3 = \frac{a_2}{4}, \dots
\]
Provides a specific underdamped oscillation pattern – reasonably fast decay with some overshoot.



 



These criteria are historically used for hand-tuning PID controllers without full modeling.
In modern design, you might optimize a cost function numerically, but these rules still show up on plant floors as “rules of thumb.”

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Problem Example: Choosing a Response
Scenario: You are tuning a temperature loop. A step change in setpoint causes the following:

Tuning A:

\(e_{\max} = 8^{\circ}\text{C}\), \(t_D = 1.0\ \text{min}\).

Tuning B:

\(e_{\max} = 2^{\circ}\text{C}\), \(t_D = 4.0\ \text{min}\).


Specification: maximum allowable deviation is \(\pm 3^{\circ}\text{C}\).
Question: Which tuning is acceptable, and which would you choose if you must also keep product quality high?

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Solution Walkthrough

Check specification:

Allowable deviation ±3°C from setpoint.

Evaluate Tuning A:

\(e_{\max} = 8^{\circ}\text{C} > 3^{\circ}\text{C}\).
Violates spec → unacceptable.

Evaluate Tuning B:

\(e_{\max} = 2^{\circ}\text{C} \le 3^{\circ}\text{C}\).
Meets spec, even though it is slower.

Choose Tuning B:

Better steady-state and transient within allowable band.
For product quality, overshoot and undershoot beyond tolerance are more damaging than slower settling.








Tip


Key lesson: Performance specs constrain tuning choices – sometimes you must accept slower response to maintain quality and safety.




Use this example to reinforce: Always start from the specification (allowed band, safety constraints) and work backwards to tuning.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
section: Analog vs Digital Processing in Control
text:
Analog vs Digital Processing in Control
Historically:

Controllers were analog electronic circuits using op-amps, resistors, capacitors → analog processing.
Now, most controllers are implemented by digital computers / microcontrollers → digital processing.

Analog processing:

Variables represented by continuous voltages/currents.

Digital processing:

Variables represented as binary numbers (bits) in a computer.

We still use analog sensors/actuators, but internal control logic is often digital.

Remind students they’ve seen analog circuits (op-amp PID implementations) and digital control (microcontroller reading ADC and writing PWM).
Industrial process control is essentially the same, just at plant scale, with more safety and robustness.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Analog vs Digital Data Representation


Analog Data

Smooth, continuous relationship between variable \(c\) and representation \(b\).
Every small change \(\delta c\) produces a proportional change \(\delta b\).
Can be linear or nonlinear.




FIGURE 11a: Analog relation \(b(c)\).



Digital Data

Variable \(c\) represented by discrete numeric value \(n\) (binary).
Limited resolution: many nearby \(c\) values map to the same \(n\).
Small changes may produce no change in code until threshold is passed.




FIGURE 11b: Digital relation \(n(c)\).




Clarify that in modern systems, sensors usually output analog voltages/currents; then an ADC converts them to digital for processing.
Nonlinearity in analog representation can be compensated numerically by the digital controller.

section: ADCs and DACs in Control Loops
text:
ADCs and DACs in Control Loops



FIGURE 12: Example of ADC converting voltage into 4-bit digital signal.



ADC (Analog-to-Digital Converter):

Converts analog sensor output (e.g., voltage) into digital code for the computer.

DAC (Digital-to-Analog Converter):

Converts digital controller output into an analog voltage or current for actuators.


In process control:

Sensors → analog → ADC → computer → DAC → analog actuators (valves, heaters).


Remind students that in embedded systems, they often use ADCs and PWM as a DAC-equivalent to control motors or heaters.
In process plants, DAC outputs often drive 4–20 mA loops or I/P (current-to-pressure) converters.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
ON/OFF Control – Basic Digital Behavior



FIGURE 13: Elementary ON/OFF temperature control system.



Final control elements (heater/cooler) have only two states: ON or OFF.
Controller output is effectively a single bit: 0 or 1.
Sensor and signal conditioning are analog, but decision is digital: \[
V_e = K(V_{\text{ref}} - V)
\]

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Analog Control – Continuous Action



FIGURE 14: Analog heater control with continuous output.


In true analog control:

All variables are analog representations of physical quantities.
Heater power \(Q\) is an analog function of excitation voltage \(V_Q\).
Error signal \(E\) is analog: difference between reference \(V_{\text{ref}}\) and measured \(V_T\).

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Supervisory vs Direct Digital Control


Supervisory Control



FIGURE 15: Supervisory computer monitoring analog loops.



Analog loops (like Figure 14) still do the real-time control.
Computer monitors multiple loops and adjusts setpoints via ADC/DAC.
If computer fails, analog loops continue using last setpoints.


Direct Digital Control (DDC)



FIGURE 16: Direct digital control loop.



Controller function implemented entirely in software.
ADC reads process variable; controller computes output; DAC drives actuator.
Analog loop is replaced by digital logic.



Historically, supervisory control was an intermediate step when computers were unreliable.
Today, with highly reliable embedded processors, DDC is dominant, often distributed across smart sensors and local controllers.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Smart Sensors and Networked Control
Smart Sensor:

Sensor + signal conditioning + ADC + microcontroller + (optionally) DAC in one housing.
May output:

4–20 mA to a valve, or
Digital data over a fieldbus (industrial LAN).

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Programmable Logic Controllers (PLCs)

PLCs evolved from electromechanical relay logic.
Designed to control discrete-state devices: conveyors, valves, motors (ON/OFF).
Programmed using ladder logic, function blocks, or structured text.

Modern PLCs can:

Implement DDC for analog loops.
Interface with smart sensors and fieldbus networks.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Worked Example – Pressure Unit Conversion
Example: Express \(p = 2.1 \times 10^{3}\ \text{dyne/cm}^2\) in pascals.
We know:

\(10^2\ \text{cm} = 1\ \text{m}\).
\(10^5\ \text{dyne} = 1\ \text{N}\).

So:
\[
p = \left(2.1 \times 10^{3}\ \frac{\text{dyne}}{\text{cm}^2}\right)
\left(10^{2}\ \frac{\text{cm}}{\text{m}}\right)^2
\left(\frac{1\ \text{N}}{10^{5}\ \text{dyne}}\right)
\]
Compute:

\((10^2)^2 = 10^{4}\).
\(2.1 \times 10^{3} \times 10^{4} / 10^{5} = 2.1 \times 10^{2} = 210\).

So:
\[
p = 210\ \frac{\text{N}}{\text{m}^2} = 210\ \text{Pa}
\]

Stress dimensional analysis: always keep track of units in each step; if the final units are N/m², you’re at Pa by definition.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
section: Metric Prefixes – Handling Very Large and Very Small Numbers
text:
Metric Prefixes – Handling Very Large and Very Small Numbers
To simplify scientific notation, SI uses standard prefixes:

\(10^{-6}\): micro (µ)
\(10^{-3}\): milli (m)
\(10^{3}\): kilo (k)
\(10^{6}\): mega (M)
\(10^{9}\): giga (G), etc.

Example: Express the following using decimal prefixes:

\(0.0000215\ \text{s}\)
\(3\,781\,000\,000\ \text{W}\)

Solution:

\[
0.0000215\ \text{s} = 21.5 \times 10^{-6}\ \text{s} = 21.5\ \mu\text{s}
\]
\[
3\,781\,000\,000\ \text{W} = 3.781 \times 10^{9}\ \text{W} = 3.781\ \text{GW}
\]


Metric prefixes show up constantly in instrumentation specs: kPa, mA, µV, Gbps.
Encourage students to mentally map between scientific notation and prefixes.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Analog Transmission Standards: 4–20 mA



FIGURE 19: Current and pneumatic signals in a plant.


Most common electrical transmission standard: 4–20 mA.

E.g., temperature range 20–120°C encoded as 4–20 mA.
20°C → 4 mA; 120°C → 20 mA.
0 mA typically used to indicate fault (broken wire, device failure).

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Example – 4–20 mA Temperature Mapping
Example 7:
Temperature range: 20–120°C mapped linearly to 4–20 mA.
Find:

Current for \(T = 66^{\circ}\text{C}\).
Temperature corresponding to \(I = 6.5\ \text{mA}\).

Derive linear relation:
Assume \(I = mT + I_0\).
At \(T = 20^{\circ}\text{C}\), \(I = 4\ \text{mA}\):
\[
4 = 20m + I_0
\]
At \(T = 120^{\circ}\text{C}\), \(I = 20\ \text{mA}\):
\[
20 = 120m + I_0
\]

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Pneumatic Signal Standard
In pneumatic systems (air pressure in pipes):

Common standard (US): 3–15 psi.
For SI: 20–100 kPa is an equivalent standard.
A measured variable is converted to proportional air pressure.
Pressure propagates down long pipes without requiring electricity.

Advantages:

Intrinsically safe in explosive environments.
Historically reliable before widespread electronics.


Mention that even in modern plants, pneumatic actuators remain common, but their setpoints are now often driven by I/P (current-to-pressure) converters controlled by DDC systems.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Key Instrumentation Definitions (Block Model)



FIGURE 21: Block with input x(t), output y(t), transfer function.



Transfer function \(T(x, y, t)\): relationship between input \(x(t)\) and output \(y(t)\).

Static transfer function: when input is constant (no time variation).
Dynamic transfer function: when input/time variation matters (often differential equations).


Examples:

Static: Flow meter, \(Q = 119.5 \sqrt{\Delta p}\).
Dynamic: First-order lag, second-order system, etc. (later sections).

Error in control context:

For measurements: difference between actual value and measured indication.
For control: difference between setpoint and measured controlled variable.


Make sure students understand that “transfer function” here is more general than the Laplace-domain concept; here it can simply be input–output relationships, static or dynamic.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Accuracy – Ways It Is Specified
Accuracy describes maximum expected error in instrument output.
Common forms:

As a fixed value: e.g., ±2°C.
As % of full-scale (FS): e.g., ±0.5% FS on 0–5 V → ±0.025 V.
As % of span: e.g., ±3% of span on 20–50 psi → ±0.9 psi.
As % of reading: e.g., ±2% of reading at 2 V → ±0.04 V.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
System Accuracy – Combining Errors
Consider two cascaded blocks:



FIGURE 22: Uncertainties build up through blocks.


Output voltage:
\[
V \pm \Delta V = (K \pm \Delta K)(G \pm \Delta G) C
\]
Approximating for small uncertainties:
\[
\frac{\Delta V}{V} \approx \pm \frac{\Delta K}{K} \pm \frac{\Delta G}{G}
\tag{5}
\]
So worst-case fractional error is the sum of individual fractional errors.
More realistic rms combination:
\[
\left[\frac{\Delta V}{V}\right]_{\text{rms}}
= \pm \sqrt{\left(\frac{\Delta K}{K}\right)^2 + \left(\frac{\Delta G}{G}\right)^2}
\]

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Sensitivity, Hysteresis, Resolution, Linearity



FIGURE 23: Hysteresis in a transfer curve.



Sensitivity: change in output per change in input.

Example: 5 mV/°C.

Hysteresis: different output for same input depending on direction of change (up vs down).

Usually specified as % FS of max deviation between increasing and decreasing curves.

Process-Control Drawings: P&ID Overview
Piping and Instrumentation Diagrams (P&IDs) show:

Process equipment (tanks, reactors, pumps).
Product flow lines (usually heavy lines).
Instruments: sensors, transmitters, controllers, valves, PLCs, computers.
Signal types: analog current, pneumatic, digital bus.

TT/301: temperature transmitter.
TC/301: temperature controller (accessed from control room).
PY/301: I/P (current-to-pressure) converter.
FT/302: flow transmitter; FC/302: flow controller; FR/302: flow recorder.

text:
Summary / Key Points

Control evaluation

Error \(e(t) = r - c(t)\) is central.
Three main objectives: stability, good steady-state regulation, and good transient regulation.

Response criteria

Damped vs cyclic responses.
Metrics: duration \(t_D\), maximum error \(e_{\max}\).
Cyclic tuning rules: minimum area, quarter amplitude.

Analog vs digital processing

Analog: continuous voltages/currents; can be nonlinear.
Digital: discrete codes; limited resolution; requires ADC/DAC.

Formulas & Relationships Summary
Error in control loop:
\[
e(t) = r - c(t)
\]
Minimum-area cyclic criterion:
\[
A = \int |e(t)|\,dt = \text{minimum}
\]
Linear mapping example (current vs temperature):

For mapping \(T\) to \(I\): \[
I = mT + I_{0}
\]

Combining transfer-function uncertainties:

Approximate worst-case fractional uncertainty: \[
\frac{\Delta V}{V}
\approx \pm\frac{\Delta K}{K} \pm \frac{\Delta G}{G}
\tag{5}
\]
RMS combination: \[
\left[\frac{\Delta V}{V}\right]_{\text{rms}}
= \pm \sqrt{\left(\frac{\Delta K}{K}\right)^2 + \left(\frac{\Delta G}{G}\right)^2}
\]

Metric prefix usage examples:
\[
0.0000215\ \text{s} = 21.5\ \mu\text{s}
\]
\[
3.781 \times 10^{9}\ \text{W} = 3.781\ \text{GW}
\]
Sensor and system example sensitivities:

Temperature sensor: 5 mV/°C → resolution and accuracy relate voltage to temperature via: \[
\Delta T = \frac{\Delta V}{5\ \text{mV}/^{\circ}\text{C}}
\]


Encourage students to keep a personal “formula card” for this course and add these to it.
Many later problems will assume familiarity with these mappings and uncertainty combinations.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Accuracy – Ways It Is Specified
Example 8:
Temperature sensor span: 20–250°C. Measurement \(= 55^{\circ}\text{C}\).

Accuracy ±0.5% FS:


FS = 250°C → error = ±0.005 × 250 = ±1.25°C.
Actual temp: 53.75°C to 56.25°C.


Accuracy ±0.75% of span:


Span = 250–20 = 230°C → error = ±0.0075 × 230 = ±1.725°C.
Actual temp: 53.275°C to 56.725°C.


Accuracy ±0.8% of reading:


Error = ±0.008 × 55°C = ±0.44°C.
Actual temp: 54.56°C to 55.44°C.


Emphasize that these are different ways of quoting the same concept; be careful when comparing device specs, because ±1% FS can be very different from ±1% of reading.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
System Accuracy – Combining Errors
Example 11:

Transducer: \(10\ \text{mV} / (\text{m}^3/\text{s}) \pm 1.5\%\).
Signal conditioning: \(2\ \text{mA/mV} \pm 0.5\%\).

Net transfer function: \(20\ \text{mA} / (\text{m}^3/\text{s})\).
Worst-case accuracy:
\[
\frac{\Delta V}{V} = \pm (0.015 + 0.005) = \pm 0.02 = \pm 2\%
\]
RMS accuracy:
\[
\left[\frac{\Delta V}{V}\right]_{\text{rms}}
= \pm \sqrt{0.015^2 + 0.005^2}
\approx \pm 0.0158 \approx \pm 1.6\%
\]

Encourage students to always check whether a spec (e.g., ±1%) is for a single device or the whole chain.
RMS error combination is common in datasheets and standards.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Sensitivity, Hysteresis, Resolution, Linearity

Resolution: smallest change in input that produces a measurable change in output.

Often % FS.
Example 12: 0–150 N range, 0.1% FS resolution → 0.15 N smallest measurable step.

Linearity: closeness of actual transfer curve to a straight line.

Often specified as max deviation from best-fit straight line as % FS.
See Figure 24.





FIGURE 24: Nonlinearity vs best-fit straight line (5% FS).



Clarify that hysteresis is predictable if you always approach from the same direction; random reproducibility errors are not.
Resolution in digital systems is tied to 1 LSB of ADC/DAC; in analog, it is limited by noise and signal conditioning.

text:
Process-Control Drawings: P&ID Overview



FIGURE 25: Sample P&ID section with temperature and flow control.


Standard: ANSI/ISA S5.1-1984 (R1992).

Instrument symbols: circles, circles in boxes, with letter/number codes (e.g., TT/301).
Line types indicate signal nature (4–20 mA, air pressure, digital).


Stress that being able to read P&IDs is like reading schematics in electronics.
The letter codes (T, F, L, P, etc.) and line types are a standard language across the process industry.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
P&ID Examples – Signals and Controllers



FIGURE 26: Cascade level–flow control with computers and PLC.



LC/220: level controller in control room (computer).
FC/220: flow control computer in field.
YIC/225: PLC controlling a drain valve.
Digital bus indicated by solid lines with small bubbles.


Briefly decode one full loop: e.g., in Figure 26, tank level measured by LT/220 → LC/220 computes a setpoint for FC/220 → FC/220 drives valve FV/220 to control flow and thus indirectly control level.

text:
Summary / Key Points

Control architectures

ON/OFF control: simplest, widely used; introduces deadband/hysteresis.
Analog control: continuous action using analog circuits.
Supervisory control vs DDC; smart sensors; fieldbus (Foundation Fieldbus, Profibus).
PLCs for discrete and DDC duties.

SI base units and metric prefixes; be comfortable converting.
Industrial standards: 4–20 mA, 3–15 psi (20–100 kPa).

P&IDs as the schematic language of process control.
