“Why might 4–20 mA be preferred to 0–20 mA?”
“What is the difference between ±1% FS and ±1% of reading?”
“What is the advantage of supervisory control vs DDC?”

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Cyclic (Underdamped) Responsea


Another tuning approach allows oscillatory (cyclic) transient response.
Measures:

Maximum error \(e_{\max}\).
Settling time \(t_D\): time from when error first exceeds allowable band until it returns within band and stays there.

Again, tuning changes:

Number of oscillations.
Amplitude of oscillations.
Settling time.





Figure 9: Setpoint and disturbance responses with oscillations (cyclic response)









Warning


Cyclic response is acceptable only if oscillations are damped and stay within acceptable error limits.




Relate to second-order system responses in classical control: “underdamped” vs “overdamped.”
Mention that some oscillation can be acceptable if it results in faster settling than an overdamped response.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this session, you should be able to:

Explain the difference between static and dynamic (time) response of a sensor.
Describe and use the first‑order sensor time response and interpret the time constant τ.
Recognize second‑order (oscillatory) sensor responses and the roles of natural frequency and damping.
Apply concepts of significant figures to measurements, designs, and calculations.
Compute and interpret arithmetic mean and standard deviation for sensor data.
Relate standard deviation to sensor performance and the normal (bell) curve.


This entire deck covers two big themes:

Dynamic behavior of sensors (Section 7.x)
How we interpret measured values statistically (Section 8.x)

Keep tying this back to real process‑control loops:

A “slow” sensor (large τ) can make a controller look bad even if the controller is fine.
A “noisy” sensor (large σ) can make us mistrust individual readings.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
section: Static vs Dynamic Behavior of a Sensor
text:
Static vs Dynamic Behavior of a Sensor


Static transfer function

Relationship between input and output when the input is constant in time.
Example:

Thermocouple:

Input: temperature \(T\)
Output: voltage \(b\)
Static transfer: \(b = K T\) (for some range).


Used to answer:

“What output should I get at 41 °C when everything has settled?”



Dynamic (time) response

How the output changes with time when the input is changing in time.
Independent of the static transfer function.
Often characterized by how the sensor responds to a step input change.
Used to answer:

“How long before the reading is close enough to the true value after a change?”









Note


The static transfer function tells you where the output will end up. The dynamic (time) response tells you how fast and in what way it gets there.




Stress that an element can have:

A perfectly linear static transfer function (great calibration),
But terrible dynamic behavior (slow or oscillatory).

In control, both matter. Sensors are the “eyes” of the control loop—if the eyes are slow or shaky, the controller sees a distorted world.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
section: Step Response: How We Define Time Response
text:
Step Response: How We Define Time Response



Figure 27: Sensor input step and delayed output response


Concept:

Input \(c(t)\) undergoes a step change at \(t = 0\):

From \(c_i\) (initial value) to \(c_f\) (final value).

Static transfer function gives:

Before \(t=0\): output \(b_i\)
After settling: output \(b_f\)

Real sensor:

Output \(b(t)\) lags and gradually transitions from \(b_i\) to \(b_f\).








Important


A step response is a standard way to characterize dynamic behavior: “If I change the input suddenly, how does the output react over time?”




Connect to ECE examples:

Step input to a temperature sensor (placing it quickly into a hotter bath).
Step change in pressure on a pressure transducer.
LED photodiode suddenly illuminated.

Emphasize: we almost never have truly instantaneous changes in the real world, but the step response is a worst‑case test and is mathematically convenient.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
7.1 First‑Order Sensor Time Response



Figure 28: First-order exponential response to a step input


First‑order response characteristics:

Smooth, exponential approach from \(b_i\) to \(b_f\).
No oscillation or overshoot.
Described by a first‑order differential equation.

General time response for \(t \ge 0\):
\[
b(t) = b_i + (b_f - b_i)\left[1 - e^{-t/\tau}\right]
\tag{7}
\]

\(b_i\): initial output (before step).
\(b_f\): final steady‑state output.
\(\tau\): time constant of the sensor (units: seconds).


Mention that this form is identical to the response of:

An RC circuit voltage to a step input (charging capacitor).
A simple thermal system (lumped capacitance) heating up.

Students in ECE will recognize the similarity to filters. Encourage them to treat many sensors as “first‑order low‑pass elements” in the time domain.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Anatomy of the First‑Order Curve


Key properties of
\[
b(t) = b_i + (b_f - b_i)\left[1 - e^{-t/\tau}\right]
\]

At \(t = 0\):

\(b(0) = b_i\)

As \(t \to \infty\):

\(b(t) \to b_f\)

The bracket term is the fraction of total change achieved:

\[
\frac{b(t) - b_i}{b_f - b_i}
= 1 - e^{-t/\tau}
\tag{8}
\]



















Note


The dynamic model applies to the output \(b(t)\), not to the physical input \(c(t)\). The input is assumed to change instantly; the output cannot.




Point out subtle realism issue:

Equation (7) predicts a finite initial slope at \(t=0\).
Real physical sensors often start with zero slope due to internal physics. Despite that, (7) is an excellent approximation for most of the response and widely used in design and analysis.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
section: Time Constant τ and the 63% Rule
text:
Time Constant τ and the 63% Rule
Set \(t = \tau\) in Equation (8):
\[
b(\tau) - b_i
= (b_f - b_i)\left[1 - e^{-1}\right]
\tag{9}
\]
Since \(e^{-1} \approx 0.3679\):
\[
b(\tau) - b_i \approx 0.632\, (b_f - b_i)
\]
Interpretation:

At \(t = \tau\), the output has reached about 63% of the total change.
Common alternative names for \(\tau\):

63% time
response time
e‑folding time


After 5τ, from (8):
\[
b(5\tau) - b_i \approx 0.993\, (b_f - b_i)
\]
So after ≈ 5τ, the sensor output is extremely close to the final value (\(>99\%\) of the change).






Tip


Rule of thumb: for a first‑order sensor, - “1 τ to get ~63% there, - 3 τ to get ~95% there, - 5 τ to get essentially there.”




Connect to RC circuits:

For a charging capacitor in an RC circuit, the same 63% rule applies.

Discuss practical design choices:

If your process changes on a time scale of 0.1 s, but your sensor has τ = 2 s, the sensor is too slow and will significantly lag.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Interactive: Explore First‑Order Response
Adjust \(\tau\) and see how the response changes.

viewof tau = Inputs.range([0.1, 5], {step: 0.1, value: 1, label: "Time constant τ (s)"})
viewof t_max = Inputs.range([2, 20], {step: 1, value: 10, label: "Plot duration (s)"})






















Ask students:

When τ is small vs large, how does the curve look?
How much time until the output is “good enough” (e.g., within 2% of final)?

Let them see that a larger τ means a much slower rise, illustrating why fast sensors (small τ) are valuable in many control applications.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Example 15: First‑Order Temperature Sensor
A sensor measures temperature linearly with static transfer function

\(33 \text{ mV} / {}^\circ\text{C}\)
Time constant: \(\tau = 1.5\) s

The process temperature changes instantly from

\(20^\circ\text{C}\) to \(41^\circ\text{C}\) at \(t = 0\)

Tasks:

Find the sensor output at \(t = 0.75\) s.
Find the corresponding indicated temperature.
Compute the error in temperature relative to actual \(41^\circ\text{C}\).


Clarify:

The input (temperature) itself is assumed to change instantly.
The output (voltage) lags with first‑order response.

Students often mistakenly try to apply the exponential equation directly to the temperature input rather than the output variable.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Real‑Time Effects and Practical Guidance

The ideal first‑order model assumes an instantaneous step in the input.
Real processes often change more gradually → sensor lag is less severe.
Our analysis is intentionally worst case.

Practical rule:

A sensor can “track” variations well if the changes in the actual variable occur over times longer than about τ.







Tip


When choosing a sensor for a control loop: - Compare sensor time constant τ with the time scale of process changes. - For accurate tracking, aim for \(\tau_\text{sensor} \ll T_\text{process\_variation}\).




Give concrete ECE example:

Monitoring CPU temperature: temperature changes relatively slowly, so a τ of several seconds is often fine.
Monitoring RF signal envelope or high‑speed data: you need sensors with very small τ (e.g., fast ADCs, high‑bandwidth front‑ends).

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
7.2 Second‑Order Sensor Response
Some sensors show oscillatory behavior after a step input:



Figure 29: Oscillatory second-order response


Characteristics:

Output overshoots and undershoots around the final value.
Oscillations decay over time due to damping.
Described by a second‑order differential equation (similar to mass‑spring‑damper, RLC circuits).

A generic damped oscillation can be written as:
\[
R(t) \propto R_0 e^{-a t} \sin(2\pi f_n t)
\tag{10}
\]

\(R(t)\): sensor output component (oscillatory part).
\(R_0\): amplitude.
\(a\): damping constant (larger \(a\) → faster decay).
\(f_n\): natural frequency (Hz) of oscillation.


Explain analogy:

Think of a mechanical pressure sensor with internal mass and spring.
A sudden pressure step can cause the mass to overshoot and oscillate.

In ECE, RLC circuits exhibit almost identical mathematics; students should link these concepts.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Second‑Order Response: Role of \(f_n\) and \(a\)


Natural frequency \(f_n\)

Period of oscillation

\[
T_n = \frac{1}{f_n}
\]

Sensor can track inputs well if input variations are slower than this period.
If the input changes faster than \(T_n\), the output can oscillate strongly.


Damping constant \(a\)

Determines rate at which oscillations die out.
Amplitude decays as \(e^{-a t}\).
After time \(t = 1/a\):

\[
e^{-a(1/a)} = e^{-1} \approx 0.37
\]
→ amplitude dropped to about 37% of original.







Note


For second‑order sensors, two time‑related parameters matter: - How fast they oscillate (\(f_n\)). - How quickly oscillations die out (\(a\)).




Clarify that there is no simple universal step‑response formula like the first‑order case, because actual sensors can be:

Underdamped (oscillatory)
Critically damped
Overdamped

The textbook’s Equation (10) is focusing on the underdamped oscillatory component, which is often the most problematic for measurement.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Section 8: Significance and Statistics
Sensors and instruments don’t just lag; they also:

Have inherent errors (bias, noise, etc.).
Report values with limited precision (significant figures).
Produce readings that vary randomly (random errors).

We need methods to:

Avoid claiming more precision than we really have (significant figures).
Summarize and interpret multiple readings (mean and standard deviation).


Transition: Up to now we’ve focused on dynamic error (time response). Now we focus on how we report and interpret numerical values from sensors.
Stress that this is essential in lab work, data sheets, and process control decisions.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
8.1 Significant Figures: Why They Matter
Example: Digital meter reads 125 kΩ.

This does not mean exactly \(125{,}000.000\ \Omega\).
It means the resistance is closer to 125 kΩ than to 124 kΩ or 126 kΩ.

Definition: Significant figures are the digits that are actually known from a measurement or calculation.

125 kΩ → 3 significant figures.
2.21 mA → 3 significant figures.
5.0 V → 2 significant figures.







Important


Significant figures are about precision of the number you can justify, not about the correctness (accuracy) of that number.




Give mental model:

Think of significant figures as “digits you are prepared to defend in a report.”
Extra digits displayed on a calculator are often meaningless given the input data.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Significance in Measurement vs Accuracy
When using an instrument:

Significance: number of readable digits or divisions.
Accuracy: how close the reading is to the true value (given as ±% of reading or ±% of full scale).

They both matter, but are not the same.






Note


A 6‑digit meter with poor accuracy can give a very precise‑looking but wrong result. A 2‑digit meter with good accuracy can give a coarse but trustworthy result.




Example:

A 4½ digit meter reading 12.34 V with ±5% accuracy.
You should not claim “12.340 V exact”; your reading may be off by about 0.6 V.

Accuracy imposes an uncertainty range around the reading.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Example 16: Current Measurement and Uncertainty
A digital multimeter measures current through a 12.5 kΩ resistor as

\(I = 2.21\text{ mA}\) on the 10 mA scale.
Instrument accuracy: ±0.2% of full scale (FS).

Find:

Voltage across the resistor.
Uncertainty in the voltage.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Example 16: Solution

Determine significance and current uncertainty


Reading: 2.21 mA → 3 significant figures.
10 mA scale, accuracy ±0.2% FS →

\[
\Delta I = 0.002 \times 10 \text{ mA} = 0.02 \text{ mA}
\]
So \(I = 2.21 \pm 0.02\ \text{mA}\).

Compute nominal voltage using Ohm’s law:

\[
V = IR = (2.21\text{ mA})(12.5\text{ k}\Omega) = 27.625 \text{ V}
\]
Given 3 significant figures in I, we report:
\[
V \approx 27.6\ \text{V}
\]

Propagate uncertainty:


Min current: 2.19 mA → \(V_\text{min} = 27.4\) V
Max current: 2.23 mA → \(V_\text{max} = 27.9\) V

So uncertainty in V ≈ ±0.25 V, rounded to keep significance:
\[
V = 27.6 \pm 0.3\ \text{V}
\]






Warning


Report both the nominal result and a reasonable uncertainty, keeping consistent significant figures.




Stress that the ±0.3 V uncertainty is rounded so that we do not imply more precision than is justified.
This is a typical format for reporting measurement results in labs.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Significance in Calculations
Rule: The result of a calculation can have no more significant figures than the least precise number used.
Example 17:

Transfer function: \(22.4\ \text{mV}/{}^\circ\text{C}\) (3 sig figs).
Measured voltage: \(412\ \text{mV}\) (3 sig figs).

Temperature:
\[
T = \frac{412\ \text{mV}}{22.4\ \text{mV}/{}^\circ\text{C}}
= 18.392857^\circ\text{C}
\]
But inputs have only 3 significant figures → answer must be:
\[
T = 18.4^\circ\text{C}
\]






Note


Calculator output digits beyond the least significant input digit are not trustworthy and must be rounded off.




Encourage students to resist the temptation to keep all calculator digits in their final answer.
However, it is often useful to keep an extra guard digit in intermediate steps to reduce rounding error, then round at the end.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Design vs Measurement Significance
Design values (hypothetical, ideal):

If a design specifies 1.1 kΩ, we treat it as exactly 1100 Ω.
If we assign 4.7 V across it, then \(I = 4.7 / 1.1\text{k} = 4.2727272\ \text{mA}\) is okay as an exact calculation in design stage.

Measurement values (real, finite precision):

If we measure \(R = 1.1\ \text{k}\Omega\) (2 sig figs) and \(V = 4.7\ \text{V}\) (2 sig figs),

Report \(I \approx 4.3\ \text{mA}\) (2 sig figs).








Important


In design problems: treat specified values as exact. In measurement problems: treat given digits as the significant figures.




Point out that textbooks often mix both kinds of problems; pay attention to context.

If the problem says “design a circuit with 4.7 kΩ,” it’s a design value.
If it says “a resistor was measured to be 4.7 kΩ,” it’s a measured value.

The treatment of significant figures is different in each case.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
section: 8.2 Statistics: Why Use Averages and Spread?
text:
8.2 Statistics: Why Use Averages and Spread?
Consider many readings of the same variable:

Each reading includes random errors.
We want to estimate a “best value” and how spread out the readings are.

Two key tools:

Arithmetic mean (average)
Standard deviation (measure of spread)







Note


A single reading can be misleading. Collections of readings + statistics give a more reliable picture of the true value and sensor performance.




Connect to calibration:

When calibrating a sensor, we often take multiple readings at each calibration point.
The mean helps identify the sensor’s systematic behavior; the standard deviation indicates measurement repeatability.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Arithmetic Mean
Given \(n\) measurements \(x_1, x_2, \dots, x_n\):
\[
\bar{x} = \frac{x_1 + x_2 + \cdots + x_n}{n}
\tag{11}
\]
Using the summation symbol:
\[
\bar{x} = \frac{\sum x_i}{n}
\tag{12}
\]

\(\bar{x}\): arithmetic mean
\(\sum x_i\): sum of all values
\(n\): number of values







Tip


The mean is often our best estimate of the “true” value when random errors are present and no other biases are known.




Remind students that for digital systems, averaging is easy and helps reduce random noise (e.g., oversampling and averaging ADC readings).
Also, mention that averaging multiple sensor readings in different locations (e.g., temperatures in a reactor) provides a meaningful overall process variable.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Standard Deviation: Measuring Spread
Given \(n\) values \(x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n\) with mean \(\bar{x}\):

Compute deviations:

\[
d_i = x_i - \bar{x}
\]

Standard deviation:

\[
\sigma = \sqrt{\frac{d_1^2 + d_2^2 + \cdots + d_n^2}{n - 1}}
\tag{13}
\]
Or, with summation:
\[
\sigma = \sqrt{\frac{\sum d_i^2}{n - 1}}
\tag{14}
\]
Interpretation:

Larger \(\sigma\) → readings are more spread out around the mean.
Smaller \(\sigma\) → readings cluster more tightly around the mean.







Note


In experimental practice, we use \(n-1\) in the denominator (not \(n\)) to get an unbiased estimate of the population variance.




Remind:

\(n\) is the number of samples; using \(n-1\) is standard in experimental statistics (sample standard deviation).
Students will see this again in probability and statistics courses.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Example 18: Room Temperature Measurements
Eight temperature readings in a room:

\(21.2^\circ\), \(25.0^\circ\), \(18.5^\circ\), \(22.1^\circ\), \(19.7^\circ\), \(27.1^\circ\), \(19.0^\circ\), \(20.0^\circ\) C

Find:

Arithmetic mean temperature.
Standard deviation.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Example 18: Solution

Mean temperature using Equation (11):

\[
\bar{T} = \frac{21.2 + 25.0 + 18.5 + 22.1 + 19.7 + 27.1 + 19.0 + 20.0}{8}
= 21.6^\circ\text{C}
\]

Standard deviation using Equation (13):

\[
\sigma = \sqrt{\frac{(21.2 - 21.6)^2 + (25.0 - 21.6)^2 + \cdots + (20.0 - 21.6)^2}{8 - 1}}
\]
Result:
\[
\sigma = 3.04^\circ\text{C}
\]
Interpretation:

Mean room temperature ≈ 21.6 °C.
Typical variation about mean is about 3 °C across sampled locations.


Point out physical interpretation:

Could indicate poor mixing of air or non‑uniform heating.
In process control, such spatial variability may matter (e.g., in reactors, ovens).

Relate: a smaller σ would mean temperature is more uniform across the room.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Visualizing Standard Deviation



Figure 30: Distributions for two sensors with different σ



Both sensors measure the same true value \(V\).
Sensor A: narrow distribution → small σ.
Sensor B: wide distribution → large σ.

Implications:

Any single reading from Sensor A is more likely to be close to \(V\).
For Sensor B, readings vary more; averaging more samples may be needed to estimate \(V\).







Important


Standard deviation quantifies repeatability and noise level of sensor readings.




Relate to ECE:

Compare two ADCs: one with low input‑referred noise (low σ), and another noisier ADC (high σ).
In digital communications, σ is related to noise power and error probability.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Normal (Gaussian) Distribution and σ
If we assume:

Errors are truly random, and
We have a large number of samples,

the distribution of readings often approaches a normal (bell) curve.
For a normal distribution:

About 68% of readings lie within ±1σ of the mean.
About 95.5% within ±2σ.
About 99.7% within ±3σ.

Example: Mean pressure 44 psi.

Case 1: \(\sigma = 14\) psi → 68% of readings between 30 and 58 psi.
Case 2: \(\sigma = 3\) psi → 68% of readings between 41 and 47 psi.







Note


Smaller σ → tighter cluster → more reliable individual readings.




Mention this rule as the 68‑95‑99.7 rule.
This helps students reason about the probability of extreme measurement values and how likely an outlier is.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
section: Example 19: Evaluating a Control System with Statistics
text:
Example 19: Evaluating a Control System with Statistics
A system packages potato chips into 200 g bags.
Samples (15 bags) drawn before control system installed:
201, 205, 197, 185, 202, 207, 215, 220, 179, 201, 197, 221, 202, 200, 195
Samples after control system installed:
197, 202, 193, 210, 207, 195, 199, 202, 193, 195, 201, 201, 200, 189, 197
Tasks:

Compute mean and standard deviation before and after.
Evaluate whether the system improved performance.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Example 19: Solution and Interpretation
Using Equations (12) and (14):
Before control system:

Mean:

\[
\bar{W}_b = 202\ \text{g}
\]

Standard deviation:

\[
\sigma_b = 11\ \text{g}
\]
After control system:

Mean:

\[
\bar{W}_a = 199\ \text{g}
\]

Standard deviation:

\[
\sigma_a = 5\ \text{g}
\]
Interpretation:

Target is 200 g.
Mean moved from 202 g → 199 g → closer to target overall.
Spread (σ) reduced by about a factor of 2 (11 g → 5 g).

If we use the ±3σ rule:

Before: \(99\%\) of bags ≈ \(202 \pm 33\) g → 169 to 235 g.
After: \(99\%\) of bags ≈ \(199 \pm 15\) g → 184 to 214 g.

So, the control system tightened the distribution and reduced systematic deviation from target.






Tip


Combining mean and standard deviation gives a richer view of system performance than either alone.




Note that even though the mean moved slightly below 200 g, the reduced spread is usually desirable (less giveaway, more consistency).
This example strongly parallels sensor calibration:

After calibration or control redesign, we want outputs closer to target and less variable.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Summary / Key Points

Static vs dynamic response

Static transfer function: relates steady‑state output to input.
Dynamic (time) response: describes how output changes over time after input changes.

First‑order sensor response

Exponential approach: \(b(t) = b_i + (b_f - b_i)(1 - e^{-t/\tau})\).
Time constant τ:

1τ → ~63% of final change.
5τ → ~99% of final change.


Second‑order response

Oscillatory with damping: \(R(t) \propto R_0 e^{-a t} \sin(2\pi f_n t)\).
Natural frequency \(f_n\) and damping constant \(a\) are sensor characteristics.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Formula Summary
First‑order sensor step response:
\[
b(t) = b_i + (b_f - b_i)\left[1 - e^{-t/\tau}\right]
\tag{7}
\]
Fraction of total change achieved at time \(t\):
\[
\frac{b(t) - b_i}{b_f - b_i} = 1 - e^{-t/\tau}
\tag{8}
\]
At \(t = \tau\):
\[
b(\tau) - b_i = (1 - e^{-1})(b_f - b_i) \approx 0.632 (b_f - b_i)
\tag{9}
\]
Second‑order oscillatory response component:
\[
R(t) \propto R_0 e^{-a t} \sin(2\pi f_n t)
\tag{10}
\]

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Summary / Key Points

Significant figures

Never claim more digits than measurement supports.
Calculated results cannot have more significant figures than the least precise input.
Design values vs measurement values are treated differently.

Statistics of measurements

Mean \(\bar{x}\): central value of readings.
Standard deviation σ: spread of readings; quantifies repeatability/noise.
Normal distribution:

~68% within ±1σ, ~95.5% within ±2σ, ~99.7% within ±3σ.




Encourage students to:

Always check both dynamic characteristics and statistical behavior when evaluating a sensor for a control application.
Use τ, σ, significant figures, and uncertainty consciously in lab reports and designs.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
Sensor Time Response and Statistical Analysis
text:
Understanding Sensor Behavior over Time


Static vs. Dynamic

Static Transfer Function: Defines output when input is constant.
Dynamic Transfer Function (Time Response): Defines how output changes when input varies in time.

Importance
Sensors provide the “knowledge” of the controlled variable. Lag or oscillation in measurement can lead to control errors.

























In this section, we distinguish between static and dynamic behavior. While the static function tells us the steady-state value, the dynamic response tells us how we get there. This is critical for ECE students because control loops depend on timely data. If a sensor lags, the controller is acting on “old” information.

title: Sensor Time Response and Statistical Analysis
text:
First-Order Response
The most common sensor response, characterized by an exponential approach to the final value.
General Equation: \[b(t) = b_i + (b_f - b_i)[1 - e^{-t/\tau}]\]

\(b_i\): Initial sensor output.
\(b_f\): Final sensor output.
\(\tau\): Time Constant (Characteristic of the sensor).







Note


At \(t = \tau\), the output has reached 63.2% of its total change.
At \(t = 5\tau\), the output has reached 99.3% (considered settled).




The first-order response is derived from a first-order differential equation, typically representing systems with a single energy storage element (like thermal mass in a thermometer or a capacitor in an RC filter). Note that the slope is steepest at t=0, which is a theoretical approximation of real-world sensors.

title: Sensor Time Response and Statistical Analysis
Sensor Time Response and Statistical Analysis
text:
Second-Order Response
Characterized by oscillation (ringing) before settling at the final value.
General Nature: \[R(t) \propto R_0 e^{-at} \sin(2\pi f_n t)\]



\(a\): Damping constant (determines how fast oscillations decay).
\(f_n\): Natural frequency (speed of oscillation).
Tracking Rule: The sensor tracks well if the input changes slower than the period of \(f_n\).








Common Examples



Accelerometers
Pressure diaphragms
Mechanical galvanometers






Second-order systems involve two energy storage elements (like an LC circuit or a mass-spring system). The damping constant ‘a’ is critical; if it’s too low, the system rings for a long time, leading to measurement errors during the transient period.

title: Sensor Time Response and Statistical Analysis
Sensor Time Response and Statistical Analysis
text:
Significance in Measurement
Accuracy \(\neq\) Significant Figures.

Significant Figures: The digits actually read or known from a measurement.
Rule of Thumb: Your result can have no more significance than the least significant number used in the calculation.

Example: The Digital Dilemma
A 12-digit calculator might show \(18.392857^\circ\text{C}\), but if your sensor only has 3 significant figures, the answer is \(18.4^\circ\text{C}\).






Important


Design values (e.g., “a \(1.1\text{k}\Omega\) resistor”) are often treated as exact in theory, but measurements of those components must respect physical limitations.




Students often fall into the trap of providing 10 decimal places because their calculator provides them. It’s vital to emphasize that these extra digits are physically meaningless if the original measurement was only accurate to two or three places.

title: Sensor Time Response and Statistical Analysis
text:
Statistics: Mean and Standard Deviation
Confidence in measurements is improved via statistical analysis of random errors.
Arithmetic Mean (\(\bar{x}\)): \[\bar{x} = \frac{\sum x_i}{n}\]
Standard Deviation (\(\sigma\)): \[\sigma = \sqrt{\frac{\sum (x_i - \bar{x})^2}{n-1}}\]
\(\sigma\) measures the spread of data. A smaller \(\sigma\) means the sensor is more precise (readings are tightly clustered).

The arithmetic mean provides the “best estimate” of the true value, while the standard deviation provides the “uncertainty” or “precision” of that estimate. In process control, we use these to determine if a process is stable or if a sensor is failing.

title: Sensor Time Response and Statistical Analysis
text:
Interactive: The Normal Distribution
Visualize how \(\sigma\) changes the “Peakedness” of sensor readings.

viewof sigma = Inputs.range([0.5, 3.0], {value: 1.0, step: 0.1, label: "Std Deviation (σ)"});













This “Bell Curve” represents random errors. As you decrease sigma, the curve becomes taller and narrower. This represents a “High Quality” or “Precise” sensor. Remember the 68-95-99.7 rule: 99.7% of all readings fall within \(\pm 3\sigma\).

title: Sensor Time Response and Statistical Analysis
text:
Case Study: Control System Success
Problem: Evaluate a potato chip packaging system (Goal: 200g).


Before Control

Mean \(\bar{W}_b = 202\text{g}\)
\(\sigma_b = 11\text{g}\)
\(99\%\) range: \(202 \pm 33\text{g}\)


After Control

Mean \(\bar{W}_a = 199\text{g}\)
\(\sigma_a = 5\text{g}\)
\(99\%\) range: \(199 \pm 15\text{g}\)


Conclusion: The system moved the average closer to the target and cut the spread by 50%.

This practical example shows that ECE isn’t just about the electronics; it’s about the data. Even though the mean only moved by 3 grams, the reduction in standard deviation significantly improves the consistency of the product and reduces waste.

title: Sensor Time Response and Statistical Analysis
text:
Summary and Key Takeaways

Time Response: Sensors are not instantaneous. First-order systems lag; second-order systems oscillate.
Time Constant (\(\tau\)): Defines the “speed” of first-order sensors; 5\(\tau\) is the standard settling time.
Significance: Never report more digits than your measurement hardware can justify.
Statistics: Use \(\bar{x}\) for the average and \(\sigma\) to quantify the reliability/spread of your process.


Wrap up by reminding students that these mathematical tools allow us to predict how a control loop will behave in the real world, where things don’t change instantly and measurements aren’t always perfect.

title: Sensor Time Response and Statistical Analysis
text:
Problem 1: First-Order Temperature Sensor


Scenario:
A sensor measures temperature linearly:

Transfer Function: \(33\text{ mV}/^\circ\text{C}\)
Time Constant (\(\tau\)): \(1.5\text{ s}\)

The Event:
At \(t=0\), the temperature suddenly changes from \(20^\circ\text{C}\) to \(41^\circ\text{C}\).
Task:

Find the sensor output (voltage) at \(t = 0.75\text{ s}\).
Determine the indicated temperature and the error at that moment.








Strategy



Convert temperatures to initial and final voltages (\(b_i, b_f\)).
Apply the first-order equation: \(b(t) = b_i + (b_f - b_i)[1 - e^{-t/\tau}]\)






This problem from Example 15 in the text demonstrates the “lag” error. Even though the environment is at 41 degrees, the sensor is still transitioning. ECE students must understand that the voltage read at t=0.75s is NOT the true process value.

title: Sensor Time Response and Statistical Analysis
text:
Interactive Solution: Problem 1
Adjust the time \(t\) to see how the voltage and error evolve.

viewof t_query = Inputs.range([0, 7.5], {value: 0.75, step: 0.05, label: "Time t (s)"});













The student can see that at 0.75s (half of one time constant), the error is significant (-12.7 degrees). Note that after 5 time constants (7.5s), the error drops near zero.

title: Sensor Time Response and Statistical Analysis
text:
Problem 2: Measurement Uncertainty
Scenario:
A digital multimeter (DMM) measures current through a \(12.5\text{-k}\Omega\) resistor as \(2.21\text{ mA}\).

Scale: \(10\text{-mA}\) FS (Full Scale)
Instrument Accuracy: \(\pm 0.2\%\) FS

Task:
Calculate the voltage across the resistor and determine the total uncertainty.






Recall


Accuracy is applied to the Full Scale of the range used, not the reading itself.
\(Uncertainty = 0.002 \times 10\text{ mA} = 0.02\text{ mA}\)




This highlights the difference between reading precision and instrument accuracy. The DMM shows three digits (2.21), but the accuracy of the instrument provides a window of uncertainty around those digits.

title: Sensor Time Response and Statistical Analysis
text:
Solution: Problem 2


1. Nominal Voltage Calculation:
\(V = I \times R\)
\(V = 2.21\text{ mA} \times 12.5\text{ k}\Omega = 27.625\text{ V}\)
2. Applying Sig Figs:
Since \(2.21\) has 3 sig figs, we round to:
\(V = 27.6\text{ V}\)

3. Uncertainty Calculation:
\(\Delta I = \pm 0.02\text{ mA}\)
Range: \(2.19\text{ mA}\) to \(2.23\text{ mA}\)
\(V_{min} = 2.19 \times 12.5 = 27.375\text{ V}\)
\(V_{max} = 2.23 \times 12.5 = 27.875\text{ V}\)
Result:
\(27.6 \pm 0.3\text{ V}\)


Note how we express the uncertainty (\(\pm 0.3\)) to match the decimal place of our significant figure (\(27.6\)). Reporting \(27.625 \pm 0.25\) would be incorrect engineering practice because it implies more significance than the current measurement supports.

title: Sensor Time Response and Statistical Analysis
text:
Problem 3: Standard Deviation Analysis
Scenario:
Temperature was measured at 8 locations in a server room to check for “hot spots.”
Data (\(^\circ\text{C}\)): 21.2, 25.0, 18.5, 22.1, 19.7, 27.1, 19.0, 20.0
Task:
Calculate the Arithmetic Mean (\(\bar{x}\)) and the Standard Deviation (\(\sigma\)).






Formula Reminder


\[\bar{x} = \frac{\sum x_i}{n} \quad , \quad \sigma = \sqrt{\frac{\sum (x_i - \bar{x})^2}{n-1}}\]




In ECE, we often average multiple sensor readings (like in a server room or a chemical reactor) to get a more reliable “global” variable for the control system.

title: Sensor Time Response and Statistical Analysis
text:
Interactive Solution: Problem 3
Run the code below to calculate the statistics for the room measurements.







The standard deviation of 3.04 degrees tells us how much the temperature varies across the room. If this were a high-precision manufacturing environment, a 3-degree deviation might be unacceptably high, even if the mean (21.6) is on target.

title: Sensor Time Response and Statistical Analysis
text:
Problem 4: Evaluating Control Performance
Scenario:
A potato chip bagger (Target = 200g).
Before Control: \(\bar{W} = 202\text{g}, \sigma = 11\text{g}\)
After Control: \(\bar{W} = 199\text{g}, \sigma = 5\text{g}\)
Question:
Using the \(99.7\%\) (\(3\sigma\)) rule, what are the weight ranges before and after?

title: Sensor Time Response and Statistical Analysis
text:
Solution: Problem 4
Solution:

Before: \(202 \pm (3 \times 11) = 202 \pm 33\text{g}\) Range: 169g to 235g
After: \(199 \pm (3 \times 5) = 199 \pm 15\text{g}\) Range: 184g to 214g

Verdict: The system is much more consistent, reducing “underweight” complaints and “overweight” waste.

This concluding problem connects the math to business value. By reducing \(\sigma\) from 11 to 5, the engineer has significantly tightened the production tolerance, which is the primary goal of most process control systems.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Instructional Objectives
The purpose of this presentation is to introduce analog signal-conditioning methods used in process-control systems.

Define the principles of analog signal conditioning.
Analyze the impact of loading on measurement accuracy.
Evaluate passive circuits (dividers, bridges, and filters).
Design simple RC filters for noise reduction.


Welcome to the lecture on Analog Signal Conditioning.
In process control, sensors rarely provide a signal that can be plugged directly into a controller or computer.
Today, we will focus on how we transform those raw sensor signals using passive components like resistors and capacitors to make them usable.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
What is Signal Conditioning?
Signal conditioning refers to operations performed on signals to convert them into a form suitable for interfacing with other elements in a process-control loop.

Conditioned Output: Remains an analog representation of the variable.
Interface Requirement: Crucial before Analog-to-Digital Conversion (ADC).
Transfer Function: The mathematical relationship between input and output.

Example: A voltage amplifier has a transfer function \(V_{out} = G \cdot V_{in}\).



Even in a digital world, the “front end” is almost always analog.
We use the term ‘Transfer Function’ to describe how the circuit alters the signal.
If we have a sensor outputting 0.2V and we need 5V, our conditioning circuit must have a specific gain and bias.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Common Operations


1. Level & Bias Changes
Adjusting the magnitude (gain) and zero-value (offset).

Amplification: Gain \(> 1\)
Attenuation: Gain \(< 1\)

2. Linearization
Converting nonlinear sensor outputs (like CdS cells) into linear representations via circuits or software.

3. Conversions

Resistance to Voltage: Bridges.
Voltage to Current: 4-20 mA standards for transmission.

4. Filtering & Matching

Filtering: Removing 60 Hz line noise.
Impedance Matching: Preventing signal loss.



These four pillars define the engineer’s toolkit.
Level and bias adjustments are like the ‘zero’ and ‘span’ on an instrument.
Conversions are vital because while many sensors change resistance, most controllers expect voltage or current.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
The Concept of Loading
Loading occurs when connecting a measurement circuit to a sensor causes the sensor’s output voltage to drop.
Thévenin’s Theorem Model:
A sensor can be modeled as a voltage source (\(V_x\)) in series with an internal resistance (\(R_x\)).
\[V_y = V_x \left(1 - \frac{R_x}{R_L + R_x}\right)\]
To minimize loading errors, we require \(R_L \gg R_x\).

This is a critical concept for ECE students.
If you use a multimeter with low input impedance to measure a high-impedance source, your reading will be wrong.
Equation 1 shows that if the load resistance RL is not significantly larger than the source resistance Rx, the measured voltage Vy will be lower than the actual source voltage Vx.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Interactive Loading Simulation
Adjust the Load Resistance (\(R_L\)) to see how it affects the measured voltage.
Sensor: \(V_x = 10V\), \(R_{source} = 5k\Omega\).

viewof rl = Inputs.range([100, 100000], {value: 5000, step: 100, label: "Load Resistance (Ω)"});













In this simulation, watch how the error increases as RL approaches 5000 ohms.
When RL equals Rx, the voltage is halved (5V).
This demonstrates why high input impedance is a primary requirement for instrumentation amplifiers.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Voltage Divider Circuits
The simplest way to convert resistance change to voltage change.











\[V_D = \frac{R_2 V_s}{R_1 + R_2}\]
Challenges:

Nonlinear: \(V_D\) vs \(R_2\) is not a straight line.
Output Impedance: \(Z_{out} = R_1 \parallel R_2\).
Self-Heating: Current through \(R_2\) may change its temperature.


The voltage divider is common but has flaws.
The relationship between R2 and VD is hyperbolic, not linear.
Also, the current required to generate a voltage drop might heat up the sensor, leading to measurement errors.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Wheatstone Bridge
Used for high-precision measurement of small resistance changes.











Null Condition (\(V_a = V_b\)): \[R_3 R_2 = R_1 R_4\]

The Wheatstone bridge is the gold standard for resistive sensors like strain gauges. Its greatest advantage is that it provides a differential output that is zero when the bridge is balanced. This allows us to amplify only the change in signal.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Bridge Offset Voltage
When the bridge is not balanced, the offset voltage \(\Delta V\) (assuming infinite detector impedance) is:
\[\Delta V = V \left[ \frac{R_3}{R_1 + R_3} - \frac{R_4}{R_2 + R_4} \right]\]

For small changes (\(\Delta R\)), the output is approximately linear.
For large changes, the output becomes significantly nonlinear.


Note the formula. If all resistors are equal, Delta V is zero. As R4 changes slightly, Delta V changes.
Engineers must decide if the sensor’s range stays within the ‘approximately linear’ region or if software linearization is needed.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Interactive Wheatstone Bridge
Balance the bridge by adjusting \(R_3\).
Given: \(V = 10V\), \(R_1=100\Omega\), \(R_2=100\Omega\), \(R_4 (Sensor)=120\Omega\).

viewof r3_val = Inputs.range([50, 150], {value: 100, step: 0.1, label: "R3 (Ω)"});













Try to find the null point. You’ll notice that as R3 increases, the offset crosses zero.
This balance point is independent of the supply voltage stability, which is why bridges are so stable.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Lead Compensation
In industrial settings, sensors are often far from the bridge circuit. Long wires add resistance that changes with temperature.
Solution: Three-wire connection

Wire 1: In series with \(R_3\).
Wire 2: In series with \(R_4\) (sensor).
Wire 3: Power lead (carries no bridge current).

Since Wire 1 and Wire 2 are identical and experience the same environment, their resistance changes cancel out in the null equation.

This is a classic engineering solution to a “real-world” problem.
By placing one lead in each arm of the bridge, the error becomes a “common-mode” signal that the bridge naturally rejects.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Low-Pass and High-Pass Basics
Used to eliminate unwanted noise (like 60 Hz hum or high-frequency transients).
Critical Frequency (\(f_c\)):
The frequency where output power drops by half (\(-3\text{ dB}\)) or voltage drops to \(0.707 V_{in}\).
\[f_c = \frac{1}{2\pi RC}\]

Low-Pass: Passes \(f < f_c\), blocks \(f > f_c\).
High-Pass: Passes \(f > f_c\), blocks \(f < f_c\).


Filters are essential for cleaning up signals.
A low-pass filter is like a sponge that soaks up fast jitters while letting the slow, steady signal through.
We choose R and C values to set the “cutoff” point where this soaking starts.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Filter Response Interactivity
Visualize the frequency response of an RC filter. Adjust \(R\) and \(C\) to move the cutoff.

viewof r_filt = Inputs.range([100, 10000], {value: 1000, step: 100, label: "Resistance (Ω)"});
viewof c_filt = Inputs.range([0.01, 10], {value: 1, step: 0.1, label: "Capacitance (μF)"});






















The plot shows a Log-Log scale.
Notice that at low frequencies, the gain is 1.
As we pass the critical frequency (fc), the gain drops off at 20dB per decade.
If we need a sharper drop, we would cascade multiple filters.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Advanced Passive Filtering
Cascaded Filters

Used to increase the “sharpness” of the cutoff.
Loading Warning: The second stage loads the first stage.
Resulting gain is the product of individual gains (if isolated).

Band-Pass Filters

Combination of a High-Pass and a Low-Pass in series.
Defined by a lower cutoff \(f_L\) and higher cutoff \(f_H\).

Notch Filters (Twin-T)

Specifically designed to reject a very narrow range of frequencies (e.g., exactly 60 Hz).


A Twin-T notch filter is particularly useful in medical electronics like ECGs, where the 60Hz power line noise is often much larger than the heart signal itself.
However, passive notch filters are sensitive to component tolerances, often requiring precision resistors.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Summary & Key Takeaways

Signal Conditioning is the bridge between the raw sensor and the data acquisition system.
Loading is the enemy of accuracy; always ensure \(R_{in} \gg R_{source}\).
Bridges convert resistance to voltage with high precision and provide a differential “zero” reference.
RC Filters are simple but effective tools for noise management, defined by \(f_c = 1/(2\pi RC)\).


To conclude: always look at the impedances before you connect two circuits.
In our next session, we will look at how Operational Amplifiers (Op-Amps) can make these conditioning tasks much easier by providing high input impedance and active filtering.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Problem 1: Loading Effects
Scenario:
A temperature sensor has an output resistance of \(5.0 \, \text{k}\Omega\) and a transfer function of \(20 \, \text{mV/}^\circ\text{C}\).
It is connected to an amplifier with an input resistance of \(10 \, \text{k}\Omega\) and a gain of 10.
Task:
Calculate the actual amplifier output voltage when the temperature is \(50^\circ\text{C}\).

Students often calculate the “ideal” value first (1.0V). The key is to realize the sensor acts as a Thévenin source, and the amplifier’s input resistance acts as a load. This demonstrates that \(R_{in}\) must be much larger than \(R_{source}\) to maintain accuracy.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Solution 1: Loading Effects


Step 1: Ideal Sensor Output
\(V_T = (20 \, \text{mV/}^\circ\text{C}) \times 50^\circ\text{C} = 1.0 \, \text{V}\)
Step 2: Loaded Input (\(V_{in}\))
Using the loading formula:
\(V_{in} = V_T \left( \frac{R_L}{R_L + R_x} \right)\)
\(V_{in} = 1.0 \left( \frac{10 \, \text{k}\Omega}{10 \, \text{k}\Omega + 5 \, \text{k}\Omega} \right) = 0.67 \, \text{V}\)

Step 3: Amplifier Output
\(V_{out} = \text{Gain} \times V_{in}\)
\(V_{out} = 10 \times 0.67 \, \text{V} = 6.7 \, \text{V}\)
Conclusion:
Without considering loading, we would have expected \(10 \, \text{V}\).
The error is a staggering 33%.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Problem 2: Voltage Divider Design
Scenario:
A supply voltage \(V_s = 5.0 \, \text{V}\) is connected to a divider where \(R_1 = 10.0 \, \text{k}\Omega\).
\(R_2\) is a sensor that varies from \(4.0 \, \text{k}\Omega\) to \(12.0 \, \text{k}\Omega\).
Task:

Find the range of the output voltage \(V_D\).
Determine the maximum power dissipated by the sensor.


Dividers are the simplest conversion circuits. Note how the output voltage doesn’t change linearly with R2. Power dissipation is critical to avoid “self-heating” errors in thermal sensors.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Solution 2: Voltage Divider
1. Output Voltage Range:

At \(R_2 = 4 \, \text{k}\Omega\): \(V_{D} = \frac{5 \times 4}{10 + 4} = 1.43 \, \text{V}\)
At \(R_2 = 12 \, \text{k}\Omega\): \(V_{D} = \frac{5 \times 12}{10 + 12} = 2.73 \, \text{V}\)

2. Power Dissipation (\(P = V^2 / R\)):

\(P_{min} = \frac{(1.43)^2}{4000} \approx 0.51 \, \text{mW}\)
\(P_{max} = \frac{(2.73)^2}{12000} \approx 0.62 \, \text{mW}\)







Tip


In ECE design, always check if \(0.62 \, \text{mW}\) exceeds the sensor’s power rating to prevent damage or bias.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Problem 3: Bridge Resolution
Scenario:
A Wheatstone bridge has \(R_1 = R_2 = R_3 = R_4 = 120 \, \Omega\) and \(V = 10.0 \, \text{V}\).
A Digital Voltmeter (DVM) with \(100 \, \mu\text{V}\) resolution is used as the detector.
Task:
Find the smallest measurable change in resistance (\(\Delta R_4\)) that the DVM can detect.

Resolution defines the sensitivity of our measurement system. Even if a sensor changes resistance, if the bridge output change is smaller than the DVM resolution, we can’t see it.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Solution 3: Bridge Resolution
The offset voltage is:
\(\Delta V = \frac{V R_3}{R_1 + R_3} - \frac{V (R_4 - \Delta R)}{R_2 + (R_4 - \Delta R)}\)
Given \(\Delta V = 100 \, \mu\text{V}\), \(V = 10 \, \text{V}\), and \(R = 120 \, \Omega\):
\(10^{-4} = \frac{10(120)}{240} - \frac{10(120 - \Delta R)}{120 + (120 - \Delta R)}\)
\(10^{-4} = 5 - \frac{1200 - 10\Delta R}{240 - \Delta R}\)
Solving for \(\Delta R\):
\(\Delta R \approx 0.0048 \, \Omega\)
Result: The bridge can resolve a resistance change as small as \(4.8 \, \text{m}\Omega\).

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Problem 4: AC Bridge Balance
Scenario:
An AC bridge is at null.
\(Z_1 = 1 \, \text{k}\Omega\) (Resistor). \(Z_2 = 2 \, \text{k}\Omega\) (Resistor). \(Z_3 = 1 \, \text{k}\Omega\) resistor in series with a \(1 \, \mu\text{F}\) capacitor.
Task:
Find the equivalent resistance (\(R_x\)) and capacitance (\(C_x\)) for the unknown arm \(Z_x\).

In AC bridges, we must balance both the real (magnitude) and imaginary (phase) parts. The frequency (\(\omega\)) usually cancels out in simple RC bridges, making the balance independent of frequency.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Solution 4: AC Bridge Balance
Null Condition: \(Z_1 Z_x = Z_2 Z_3\)
\(R_1 (R_x - \frac{j}{\omega C_x}) = R_2 (R_3 - \frac{j}{\omega C})\)
Equating Real Parts:
\(R_1 R_x = R_2 R_3 \implies R_x = \frac{R_2 R_3}{R_1} = \frac{(2\text{k})(1\text{k})}{1\text{k}} = 2 \, \text{k}\Omega\)
Equating Imaginary Parts:
\(\frac{R_1}{\omega C_x} = \frac{R_2}{\omega C} \implies C_x = C \frac{R_1}{R_2} = (1 \, \mu\text{F}) \frac{1\text{k}}{2\text{k}} = 0.5 \, \mu\text{F}\)

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Problem 5: Low-Pass Filter Design
Requirement:
A signal contains data at \(f < 1 \, \text{kHz}\) but has noise at \(1 \, \text{MHz}\). Design a filter that attenuates the \(1 \, \text{MHz}\) noise to \(1\%\) of its original amplitude (\(V_{out}/V_{in} = 0.01\)).
Task:

Calculate the required critical frequency \(f_c\).
Select \(R\) and \(C\) values.


Engineers often start with a desired attenuation at a specific noise frequency. Then they work backward to find the cutoff frequency.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Solution 5: Low-Pass Filter
Step 1: Find \(f_c\)
\(\frac{V_{out}}{V_{in}} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 + (f/f_c)^2}}\) \(0.01 = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 + (10^6/f_c)^2}} \implies (10^6/f_c)^2 \approx 10,000\)
\(f_c = 10 \, \text{kHz}\)
Step 2: Component Selection
Pick \(C = 0.01 \, \mu\text{F}\):
\(R = \frac{1}{2 \pi f_c C} = \frac{1}{2 \pi (10^4)(10^{-8})} = 1591 \, \Omega\)
Standard Choice: Use \(R = 1.5 \, \text{k}\Omega\) or a \(1.6 \, \text{k}\Omega\) resistor.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Problem 6: Twin-T Notch Filter
Scenario:
An EKG monitor is picking up \(60 \, \text{Hz}\) interference from power lines.
Design a Twin-T notch filter to reject this specific frequency.
Task:

Find \(f_c\) for the Twin-T circuit.
If \(C = 0.1 \, \mu\text{F}\), find \(R, R_1,\) and \(C_1\).


The Twin-T is a special passive filter. Note that the notch frequency \(f_n\) is NOT equal to \(f_c\). It is \(0.785 \times f_c\). This is a common point of confusion for students.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Solution 6: Twin-T Notch Filter
Step 1: Calculate \(f_c\)
\(f_n = 0.785 f_c \implies 60 = 0.785 f_c\)
\(f_c = 76.43 \, \text{Hz}\)
Step 2: Calculate Components

\(R = \frac{1}{2 \pi f_c C} = \frac{1}{2 \pi (76.43)(10^{-7})} = 20,823 \, \Omega\)
\(R_1 = \frac{\pi R}{10} = \frac{\pi (20823)}{10} \approx 6,541 \, \Omega\)
\(C_1 = \frac{10 C}{\pi} = \frac{10 (0.1 \, \mu\text{F})}{\pi} \approx 0.318 \, \mu\text{F}\)

text:
Design your own Bridge
Use the editor below to calculate the bridge offset for your own sensor parameters.
Change r_sensor to see the effect on delta_v.







Encourage students to test “unbalanced” bridges. What happens if R1 is doubled? What happens if the supply voltage drops to 5V? This helps them build intuition for sensitivity and supply dependence.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this session, you should be able to:

Describe the ideal op amp model and use the two “golden rules” for circuit analysis.
Analyze and design basic op amp configurations:

Inverting and noninverting amplifiers
Summing amplifiers and voltage followers

Explain nonideal op amp parameters (offsets, slew rate, bandwidth) and when they matter.
Understand and design basic instrumentation circuits:

Differential / instrumentation amplifiers
Voltage‑to‑current and current‑to‑voltage converters

Implement simple integrating and differentiating op amp circuits.
Apply a structured design process to real signal‑conditioning problems.


Explicitly tie each objective to later slides: - Objectives 1–3: Sections 4.1–4.2. - Objective 4: Section 5.4 and example bridge instrumentation. - Objective 5: Sections 5.7–5.9. - Objective 6: Design guideline examples.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
Why Op Amps in Instrumentation?

Process control and measurement systems need:

Amplification and attenuation
Impedance matching
Level shifting (offsets)
Filtering and linearization
Voltage ↔︎ current conversion

Historically: built from tubes, then discrete transistors
Today: integrated‑circuit (IC) implementations dominate

Small size
Low power
Low cost
Consistent and well‑documented behavior








Tip


Think of an op amp as a universal analog building block you configure with a few external resistors and capacitors to implement many different transfer functions.




Relate this to typical ECE contexts: sensor interfaces, DAQ boards, motor controllers, biomedical instrumentation. Stress that almost all “analog front ends” hide one or more op amps inside.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
section: 4.1 Op Amp Characteristics – The Black‑Box View
text:
4.1 Op Amp Characteristics – The Black‑Box View


Symbol



Op amp symbol



Two inputs:

+ noninverting
− inverting

One output
Power pins (\(+V_s\), \(-V_s\)) typically not drawn on signal schematics


Transfer Behavior



Op amp transfer



Output vs. differential input \(V_d = V_2 - V_1\)
Large voltage gain in linear region
Saturates at \(\pm V_{\text{sat}}\) set by supply rails



Clarify the mapping between figure labels and our notation: - In the text, \(V_1\) is on the noninverting terminal (+), \(V_2\) is on the inverting terminal (−). - The differential input \(V_d = V_2 - V_1\). - When \(V_2 > V_1\) (more positive at the inverting input), the output goes negative (−). This inversion behavior is the reason for the input naming.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
Ideal Op Amp – Key Properties

Infinite open‑loop gain \(A\)

In linear region \(V_{\text{out}} = A \,(V_+ - V_-)\)
Practically \(A \gg 10^5\) even at low frequency

Infinite input impedance

No current flows into \(V_+\) or \(V_-\)

Zero output impedance

Output acts as an ideal voltage source

Infinite bandwidth, zero noise, no offsets (in the ideal model)

These properties lead to two powerful analysis rules when negative feedback is used.






Important


Golden Rules for Ideal Op Amps (with negative feedback):

No current flows into the input terminals: \(I_+ = I_- = 0\).
The inputs are at the same voltage: \(V_+ = V_-\).





Emphasize that these rules are not fundamental device physics; they are approximations that hold because the open‑loop gain is huge and feedback forces the input difference to be near zero. Also highlight: these rules apply only when the op amp is not saturated and there is a feedback path from output to at least one input.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
Visualizing Op Amp Saturation












If the differential input is more than a few hundred µV, the output hits \(\pm V_{\text{sat}}\).
Only a very narrow band around \(V_+ \approx V_-\) is linear.


Connect this to comparator behavior: - An op amp with no feedback effectively acts like a comparator: output is either high or low depending on the sign of \(V_+ - V_-\). - For analog amplification applications we always add feedback to force the op amp to operate in the narrow linear region.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
Ideal Inverting Amplifier – Circuit



Inverting amplifier



Input \(V_{\text{in}}\) through \(R_1\) to the inverting (−) input
Feedback resistor \(R_2\) from output to inverting node
Noninverting (+) input connected to ground
The inverting node is called the summing point or virtual ground


Point out: the inverting input is at a virtual ground (0 V) because ideal feedback keeps \(V_- = V_+ = 0\) V, but no current flows into the input, so this point is not actually connected to physical ground. This distinction is important when considering input and feedback currents.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
Ideal Inverting Amplifier – Derivation
At the summing node (inverting input), apply KCL and the two golden rules.

Rule 1: No current into input → sum of resistor currents is zero.
Rule 2: \(V_- = V_+ = 0\) V (since \(V_+ = 0\)).

Currents:

Through \(R_1\): \(I_1 = \dfrac{V_{\text{in}} - 0}{R_1} = \dfrac{V_{\text{in}}}{R_1}\)
Through \(R_2\): \(I_2 = \dfrac{V_{\text{out}} - 0}{R_2} = \dfrac{V_{\text{out}}}{R_2}\)

KCL:
\[
I_1 + I_2 = 0 \tag{29}
\]
Substitute:
\[
\frac{V_{\text{in}}}{R_1} + \frac{V_{\text{out}}}{R_2} = 0 \tag{30}
\]
Solve for \(V_{\text{out}}\):
\[
V_{\text{out}} = -\frac{R_2}{R_1} V_{\text{in}} \tag{31}
\]

Gain magnitude: \(\left|\dfrac{V_{\text{out}}}{V_{\text{in}}}\right| = \dfrac{R_2}{R_1}\)
180° phase inversion (sign change)







Note


The input impedance seen by \(V_{\text{in}}\) is approximately \(R_1\).




Relate this to a simple ECE example: use an inverting amplifier to scale a 0–5 V DAC output to a 0–10 V or −10 to +10 V range. Also point out that if \(R_2 < R_1\), the circuit attenuates; if \(R_2 > R_1\), it amplifies.
